author: K Dillon 47

text: Talk about price point differences. Firstly the Porsche is by a long, long stretch the best daily driver, the all around most accurate, communicative and best looking with probably the highest residual on resale. It is probably the best driving in most real world situations, the most comfortable, the most amenities etc. The shelby is more or less about the equivalent of a 911 GTS model so pound for pound the Porsche GTS would cost around 120k. The McLaren I believe costs around 185k making it by far the most expensive car here. Hey if you are a 1% go for it! I like McLarens but of the newer models they have poor resale values. The seats are NOT comfortable over the long hall and the car is not that practical but they look cool, sound cool etc. Wonder if the look of the front fascia will look dated in under 10 years. Not so the Porsche. Even the Shelby looks great.Ôªø

text: The biggest issue I find now is that big Euro car guys are realizing they're getting beat by the American cars. Which are way cheaper. Sure, the Euros helped start off with designs but now, they're trying to shut down every last one. The Viper takes 13 track records annnd Marchionne decided to shut it down. Ford made a beautiful motor for the GT350R but has one of the ugliest mustang looks ever. Why? European designers didn't like the fact the '13 were the nicest looking cars out there. Even the Germans are screwing with us, Porsche is reallllly trying to stop Chevy from fixing the vital differential on the Z06 to fix its major oversteer. I'm only 13 years old, live in Canada and WILL NOT accept the Euro cars to take everything back. I'll start it and make it better. Just watchÔªø

author: David Myers

text:
"Best Driver's Car" (really?)

Soo, which car gives the most feedback for the road/tires through the steering wheel while still being precise? Which car has the fastest/most precise throttle/brake response? Which cars transmission gives the highest control/precision/speed to the driver? Which car has the most balanced/controllable steering ratio and slip angle? Which car has the highest quality/reliability of parts (Obviously not the Mclaren)? Which car has the most optimal suspension design/settings for the backroad (where owners drive 98% of the time)? What is the god damn octane rating for the fuel these cars even use???

This is why I have never liked Motor Trend. They're NOT real car enthusiasts, they DON'T know what the definition of a "driver's car" is, and they have no real passion or soul.

They just like fast cars that look and "feel" nice, and parrot what the manufacturers give them in their press release informational paperwork.Ôªø

author: Stuff stuff and More stuff

text: Shows don't grow on trees in TVLand.  There are things called sponsors who give the producers of a TV show money so that the producers can pay for things to make the show, like cameras and paychecks.  In return for the money they give, the producers let the sponsors put their products in the show or run advertisements during the show.  When they put products in a show, it is called "product placement." And that is how TVLand works, Johnny RASX.Ôªø

author: Erek K

text:
Where did you get the impression Jonny liked the NSX more than the GT350R?
1) The NSX placed 9th in this competition, and the GT350R 2nd (and the 1LE Camaro got 4th).
2) The Z06 was at Best Drivers Car last year...cars only compete once when they are new (frankly I think the GTS cheated this rule a bit, but it was updated supposedly).
3) This test is about the best driving new car...regardless of cost.  Yes the odds are stacked in favor of expensive cars....that's just the way it is.  They have an entire series called Head 2 Head where they compare cars that are more directly relevant.

Maybe you should take the time to be informed before spewing a long rant.Ôªø

author: Ernest Muric

text:
LOL...so you're a GTR fanboy/troll.

A few comments:
1) Top Gear is gone, so Motor Trend is producing the highest quality content available right now.  The notion that you haven't heard of them yet is just ignorance on your own part.
2) As far as objectivity goes Top Gear was laughable.  They all had their own ingrained bias that they let show quite clearly.  But in the end I don't know what you are talking about.  Clarson bought a ZR1 not a GTR.
3) Validity.  This series (unlike Top Gear) actually lets you hear from the racing driver so you get a better impression of the cars attributes.  And among their non-Pro's many of them are faster than the Top Gear trio anyway.

So while Top Gear was very entertaining, this show is vastly more accurate as far as car reviews go.Ôªø

author: Dolby109

text: You must be kidding. If you have any technical knowledge, Chevy's MUCH better. That Camaro 1LE is a 6.2 pushrod V8 that will last 250k miles and costs less than half of what the GT350r does. Those GT350 motors are having all kinds of oil starvation problems already, they're complete nightmares. I'm actually quite a fan of both companies, and I really prefer the mustang's style, but in terms of handling and reliability, GM has them beat by a mile. Even in this video, a $40k Camaro comes within 98% of the Mustangs lap time and costs half as much. Plus the Camaro's interior quality is way better, the tires are better suited for long term street driving, and it's ride quality is better. Alpha platform is just far superior.Ôªø

text:
I hate to say this, but when you connect the dots and step back. (I'm going to preface this by saying I know this is going to ignite a firestorm) Does this show the rise of Ford Performance to actually replace what BMW and M Division was to all of us car geeks of the 90s?

BMW just brought out their best drivers car yet of recent models (agreed on by all MT staff and others) and it finished 11th out of 12.

Look at what FP has brought us in the form of really great drivers cars, not necessarily the fastest cars straight line or lap times. But, really really good driving involvement and good ol' fashioned fun.

Fiesta ST
Focus ST
Focus RS
Fusion Sport (To be yet decided, but it looks good)
Mustang Shelby GT 350
Mustang Shelby GT 350R
Ford GTÔªø

And yes, actually Motor Trend in THIS video just said a GT350R is only 1.6 seconds faster per lap than a Camaro SS 1LE (1:36.11 vs 1:37.78). That means the Camaro is 98.2% as fast as the GT350R on a track, and probably exactly as fast as the regular GT350, and they actually do only cost $40k new.Ôªø

text: And here is a fun fact: The Australian police tested the Mustang as a potential highway patrol interceptor to replace their old fleet.  In the 30 years of testing cars, the Mustang was the ONLY car to fail ALL 9 safety categorise on the list.  They basically said it is only safe to drive on a closed track.  One tester said it is a potential fire bomb waiting to explode.  BMW on the  other hand passed with flying colours.  So if you prefer a dangerous car that will explode into fire when you crash it, then good luck with the Mustang.  BTW, I wanted to buy a Mustang before I read the report.  Now I think I will get a Camaro.Ôªø

author: J Slik

text: Motor Trend's "Car of the Year" for 1969 was the Plymouth Roadrunner.¬† In the late 70's I bought and cleaned up TWO '69 Roadrunners.¬† (At the time they weren't old cars.)¬† In 2016 dollars I only had about $8,500 dollars invested for both Roadrunners.¬†(In 1977 dollars I had about $2700 to buy and fix up both.)¬† Now, I'm going to spend $45K to buy a used BMW as I enter retirement years.¬† Buying, building and investing hundreds of hours into a car was a kid's hobby, now only "Rich Kids" can build a respectable ride.¬† Too bad that hot rodding has turned into an old man's game.¬† I've had a couple of Mustangs and a few MOPARS but for a really good car you have to buy European.¬† As an old "MOPAR Guy" it pains me to admit it.¬† A friend of mine just got her Mercedes AMG and it cost $200K so even us old guys aren't able to afford the best of what's out there.¬† I have to limit my retirement budget for cars to under $50K so I can pay cash.¬† We have to enjoy the really good cars on YouTube and unless you inherit wealth a middle class guy like me is almost priced out of the Game.¬† Motor Trend 1969 was affordable for even kids.¬† My how things have changed...Ôªø

author: Jay Phillips

text:
I love these best drivers car videos but I have a couple of gripes with this one:

I know there's only so many cars you can include in one video, and I get that. But a bit of an explanation as to why you chose these cars would be nice to see in the video itself. For example, why did you choose the McLaren 570s over the 675LT? And as somebody already mentioned, where was the 911R? Also, since it's best drivers car, shouldn't there be some representative of the lower end of the market here, like the Miata or the FRS/BRZ? I'm not saying you chose wrong, I'm only asking for some information regarding the choices. 

I found myself wishing for a bit more explanation during the process of picking the top 3 as well. "That thing, the AMG was in fact our best drivers car, and then it showed up this year and... no" So what exactly made you say no here? It's not so much that I disagree in any way, I just feel like the video was incomplete.

Anyway, loved the video overall! Amazing content as always.Ôªø

There is no such thing as 'tires that come with the car'. Cars can be bought (and supplied by manufacturers to tests) on different wheel sizes even. text:
Go to college, major in journalism, become very good at writing, public speaking and video production. Get the best internships you can, become an expert on a subject you love, move to L.A. or New York where you can compete amongst the best in the business, work long hours until you stand out, network as much as possible, spend your weekends at work or working on indie  projects to help your resume and remain relevant, apply for jobs over and over until someone decides you are the right match and keep working your ass off so that you are good enough to get the next job you want while fending off competitors vying for your current job. Repeat.

Super easy.Ôªø

text: Nurburgring is simply bullshit because there are no enforced or observed rules. The manufacturers can do whatever they want and say whatever they want, there is no authority to establish a set of rules and make sure they are followed. The cars can be in any state of tuning, from suspension to simply increasing the boost .... with this shitload of turbocharged cars it's stupidly easy for a manufacturer to cheat. At least with the NA cars like the Ford, it's much harder to increase horsepower for the Nurburgring 'official' record. There is nothing official about that btw, it's track testing turned into advetisment ... there's racing teams and tuners around there who will assist manufacturers with the tuning for the track ... it's bullshitÔªø

text: Shobin Drogan nobody cares that they help people with testing and development when the focus of the conversation is how good their car is. Lotus hasn't made a "great" car for a long time, and that is still the case when examining the lotus 400. Case and point- a good comparison online between the corvette grandsport and the lotus. The corvette is faster, handles better, looks better, sounds better, is Miles faster, brakes harder, and is better equipped with a dozen toys and technology options the likes of which the lotus does not have- and it's only 145 lbs heavier. Meanehile the lotus base model costs 24,000 dollars more than the Vette, and the Vette comes totally optioned out at 92k- that includes the carbon discs and aero and tech packages. 89k for a base lotus or 92k for the loaded GS that's faster and better in every way. This- this is what's wrong with lotus right now. The 400 is a good car, not a great one, like the grand sport, but they sell it at that ludicrous price. If they can recapture the magic of the Elise or esprit then maybe they will be making great cars again someday. But right now? Nope.Ôªø

author: Ethyn Payne

text:
Dear Motor Trend. STOP mixing track cars with sports cars. I warned you back in 2014 when you let Z/28 and GTR Nissmo entering the contest and then choosing Z/28 as the winner. I told you that your decision would force more and more manufacturers to send you their track cars rather than sports cars. So this year you had FOUR (4) track cars among your sports cars. 3 Race Track specialists (ACR, GT350 R, 1LE) and 1 Road Track specialist (M4 GTS). Why do you think the first 3 (and Z06) suddenly have massively wide, almost slicks and very sticky tires now? Remember those 305s of Z/28?

You should stop this as people buy sports cars to use on streets and roads and track cars to use on track. 2 very different categories that now have been mixed thanks to your mistake back in 2014. Give track cars their own contest, but don't mixe them any more. I'm afraid next year we might have a Challenger with 345s all around (full slicks), and with an even bigger wing than Viper ACR. If that is even possible.Ôªø

author: dynamichamza

text:
So the Porsche 991S won this competition in 2012 and followed it up by winning again with the 4S in 2013. It then finished in the top 3 every year since! 2014 and 15 Porsche finishes second and third. Here we are in 2016 and guess what Brand we find in the top 3 finalist yet again!
Porsche is the definition dynasty in this competition. Some 50 plus models tested over 5 years and there is a Porsche in the final three every year.
The next model up for contention is likely to be the 991.2 GTS or GT3. 
Many of these models are offered in one design with select options while Porsche has a car for every appetite. RWD or AWD! Mid engine or rear engine! A front engine Porsche super car is on the way which slots under the 918 but above the Turbo S. 
Lastly its amazing how well Porsche builds its product. Unlike many of these other cars the Porsche 911S can be a daily driver and in the 4S version can be an all season daily driver.Ôªø

1, 2 or 3 every year for the last half decade. Out of over 50 cars tested and each had to be a new model for that year. If it Ain't broke don't fix it!
If Porsche were a sports team they would be the one to beat year after year considered  most likely to be in the Super Bowl.Ôªø

Steve Jovan

text: @Steve Jovan Believe or not the GT4 is actually faster than a GTS around a track. Rest I agree.Ôªø
author: MrGhost370

text:
@MrGhost370
GT4 is a great purist Porsche but its simply is not as fast as a 911 GTS  which is by design.
No way! Not even close!
GT4 is a manual vs with a tuned down S engine putting out 385HP vs the 430HP you get in the GTS. Not counting the PDK and Sport Crono that adds to the GTS performance. Fully loaded model is what MT tests as does Porsche for top speed on all its cars.
GT4 is a great car but Porsche did not tune it to just under the S for any reason. They slotted each car to fill a certain performance range.
Porsche could put a 911 GTS engine into a Cayman or even a GT3 engine into a Cayman which would be an almost perfect car. That is an "IF" not a reality. The reality is a tuned down 991.1 S version of the engine putting out less power.
BTW I'm referring to the 911 GTS not the Cayman GTS  in case you think otherwise.

N√ºrburgring Nordschleife lap times

(2012) 991S 7:37
(2015) GT4   7:42

That's a about 5 sec slower than the 991S of 2012 not the new 991.2! 
Care to guess what it did against the 911 GTS given its that much more a 911 in every way compared to a standard S?
None of this is to degrade the GT4 as its a great car but track times don't lie and again that's by design on the part of Porsche.Ôªø

text:
COME ON! That was the Porsche 30 years ago! Today Porsche is universally considered to be the standard by which sports car are judged. Porsche has cut back on it racing and is making cars these days. 
JD Powers just listed the Lexus and Porsche as the two most reliable brands of auto makers. Lexus is no surprise but for Porsche to make that top spot says they are making great cars meaning its not for only the rich. Reliability is something companies strive for when selling to real people not the wealthy.
Secondly unlike Ferrari or Lambo the Porsche is an everyday sports car. It can be your only car today! 
Lastly Porsche is not a sports car company any longer in terms of sales. They area SUV maker that also sells sports cars. The Macan and Cayenne are not that pricey as base models.
You can buy a new Porsche today for under $46,000 US.
Its not the old Porsche!Ôªø

author: NDallas40

text: Joe.  I saw 9 GT350's at MSRP on Cars.com yesterday.  At least half of those are probably false advertising though.  The GT350 R is a different story.  The best you can hope to get on those is 5 to 10K over.  It took me about 3 months and over 100 ph. calls.  The best tool is Mustang6g.com.  They have a thread dedicated to the Shelby seekers.  If an R deal pops up, you have to act fast, so you have to check it daily.  Good luck.Ôªø
author: NDallas40

text: Big difference is how the average buyer would do in a Porsche or Mclaren vs the 350. A pro can push the 350 in away the average man can't without getting killed. The Porsche is so well planted that you can push it closer to the edge without dying. Secondly none of this is about build quality or materials which do make a difference in terms of how a car feels and what it costs. The 350 is a good car for the price but try sitting in one for a few min vs the Porsche and you quickly learn where your money goes. These are all new cars. Part of what you pay for ,in higher end sports cars, is the materials and build which is measured in the years to come. Find a 10 year old Mustang and see how its held up vs a 10 year 911. Open and close the door on each car and you will see where the extra money went.Ôªø
author: Steve Jovan

text:
Amen sir!
Also interior design... And I can hear you say "interior shmerior" , but if you think about it, that's what you are going to be seeing 90% of the time, and 100% of the time while driving. I had the opportunity to test drive a Camaro Z21, and quite frankly as soon as I sat down I thought:" Wow, I just don't care how good this car is to drive, this is fugly!", no kidding, it looked like the interior was designed by a 4 year old with a box of crayons over recess :) Never mind the materials, there was really ugly plastic everywhere... 
Sorry, I just don't want to drive that car, no matter how good it is. The way I see it, interior design for a car has to be either pure function, almost race car like, there is a certain beauty about that, or it has to be gorgeous to look at. 
And as a minor thing, but that's getting to be a bigger thing every year that passes for me, I guess I'm getting old :) A car  that is loud all the time is just god damn obnoxious,. Don't get me wrong, I love the sound of a finely tuned engine, be it a V12, V8 or V6, and it's great when you want to push it, but then I have to drive this thing around town, maybe even take it to work a couple of times, and that's when gets to be too much.. One of the reasons I sold my mint 93 camaro about 8 years ago, it had a borla exhaust that sounded great, but the damn thing would never quite the hell down! Take a trip of any considerable length on that and it starts to get on your nerves, never mind just trying to get from point a to b... It was great on my late 20, early 30's but much past that it's just annoying.Ôªø

author: Steve Jovan

text: Price is irrelevent since just like with everything else in this world at some point luxury items don't have only the manufacturing value but also a prestige value. A million dollar Patek watch doesn't also show time millions times more accurately than 100 bucks seiko.Ôªø
author: Aur0n

text:
@Aur0n 
Price is not irrelevant as it reflect things like materials and build quality. Patek watch analogy is a terrible one as a watch has one job while a great car must do a great many things well in order to be a great car.
This is why MT uses many metrics when judging a car which includes build quality. I know of no car publication that over looks shoddy build quality and and cheap materials when evaluating a car. They use a point system which considers many factors. A car might do really well in performance but score terribly in terms of build quality, comfort, interior design and so on. 
Lastly build quality and materials certainly matters in terms of how well the car holds up over time. This particular competition measured none of this as its a snap shot in time of brand new models. The quality question is one that would certainly show as time goes on but again this was not the point of this MT competition.Ôªø
author: Steve Jovan

text:
Well thats why I said that "at some point its not just manufacturing value" and you must be pretty stupid thinking that those expensive watches are just doing one thing - they can do way over 30-60 things (its called a complications) and are made from more 1500- allmost 3000 parts inside with over 1500 moving parts. Its more than in most cars..

US cars like mustang or camaros don't have prestige value - they have manufacturing value and reasonable profit value which isn't too big thanks to large production numbers. Exotic cars have manufacturing value, reasonable profit value which is combined with very unreasonable prestige value that just comes from being desirable, from legendary name and low production numbers. And for  that reason it is pointless to bring price into calculation.

But I have to agree that they use a system that considers many factors and one of them factors is that "we can look past many flaws if its a good 'ol murican V8".

But yeah, they have to put on a show because otherwise porsche would probably win every year.Ôªø
author: Aur0n

text:
@Aur0n
Expensive watches have ONE primary function which is to tell TIME correctly! Most high end watches are not Crono watches! So yes its a bad analogy!
A Patek watch costing $30,000 has one task to perform not 30!
A car has MANY tasks/ jobs that make it a bad,average,good or great car!
A watch does not need to perform differently if I'm going to be running vs walking or if I come to a sudden stop. A car does! I don't need to drive my watch, sit in my watch for hours or insure it handles well at over 100mph! I do need to be able to drive my sports car thus the different elements. Engine,chassis,suspension,steering,tires not to mention safety and comfort! What was the last watch that scored poorly on a safety test??
Again poor analogy which can't be saved by comparing the number of moving parts in each.
Secondly hate to break it to you but Porsche is owned by VW meaning its made with a great many parts it shares with other brands like Audi and VW so no its not a small car maker. Big R&D that comes from making Porsche filters down to car like VW and Audi which off set the cost of building the Porsche.
Quote
"Exotic cars have manufacturing value,combined with very unreasonable prestige value that just comes from being desirable"
ACCORDING TO WHOM?? PORSCHE IS NOT FERRARI AND THERE IS NO SHORTAGE OF 911 MODELS ANYWHERE IN AMERICA!
In short you have made statements which have no evidence to support. The rest is nothing more than YOUR opinion.
Unlike a critique of the Z06 which finished last in this competition last year. What are the odds of a brand new high end muscle car breaking? American built Muscle car that is!
Try looking at cheap build quality and poor engineering when you think about the price point of American cars vs companies like Porsche. That unlike your assertion is supported by facts. See reliability scores on the American cars!
Again see the wonderful Z06 until it started breaking down at the 5000 mile mark.Ôªø

text: Which is why rich people around the world have committed suicide, or have become drug addicts, or alcoholics.....because they were so happy being wealthy.Ôªø
author: Lifted_Above

text:
@Lifted_Above 
You need to read a bit about actual social science data! Wealthier people are in fact happier. A much higher % of lower class persons take their own life and suffer from substance abuse compared to upper middle class and well off persons.
You are confusing fame and tragedy with poverty with tragedy. No one sees a story about the thousands of poor people who over dose any given day. If you are wealthy and famous it is a story! This is why social science data is not a function of what stories made it onto ET this evening.
Example divorce is over 30% lower among people making over $300,000 a year compared to those making less than $100,000 a year.
Money does not buy happiness but it makes being unhappy much easier.Ôªø

author: toure7

text:
It doesn't matter if expensive watches have ONE primary function - cars also have ONE primary function to drive from point A to point B. You do understand that same end result doesn't mean same journey? Two cars may put down same numbers but doing so with one of them is a joy and doing so with other is not so much.

What does that mean that porsche is owned by VW - so is Bentley, Lamborghini, Bugatti - that doesn't mean that they share many parts that make them dirt cheap to make. American cars a cheap for multiple reason like getting resources domestically and cheaply, having government dotations to stay afloat so they can actually sell cars cheaper, having to share a huge local market between just 3 manufacturers so the sales numbers are huge etc.

Finally to make it short and clear - theres no charity in business - if Ford could sell shitloads of mustangs for 100k a piece they would - the thing is that they can't - porsche can because people appreciate the craftsmanship, quality, reliability etc. Only ones who don't understand it are 15 year old murican fanboys who can't stand someone else being better and who just watch dry numbers - most people with enough money would buy porsche over a mustang in a heartbeat.Ôªø

text:
u mean to tell me that you honestly believe that healthcare equals you being healthy or not? 

i had healthcare, i still felt unhealthy. they told me i was fine though. 

you control your health, eat good food regularly  and exercise regularly. stay aware of yourself and how you feel.Ôªø
author: Ceasar Clark

text:
@toure7 
What does that have to do with this issue? Being sick is more likely to happen to the less well off.Ôªø
author: Steve Jovan

text:
@Aur0n
Wrong again on the watch analogy as a watch has the same task day or night 24/7 which is not true of a sports car vs a mini van!
There is nothing about a 911 that is functional in terms of moving people or goods from A to B vs a mini van,SUV or average car! The two have next to no overlap whereas all watches have one task that being to tell time.
A 911 owner is not trying to get from one particular place to another in many cases. Its just the driving experience for many. Car goes out and comes back without any other goal or even route in mind. Who on earth takes a mini van out for a drive???
So in the end you decided to reject you initial point. Great given its means you now concede why it is that Porsche is a better car. Note that you admit that while leaving out your previous position given what buyer paid for this cheaply made ford products.
Lastly R&D is a huge part of development so yes Porsche takes a lot from its other cars and applies the technology to its sports cars. Do you need a list of what Porsche puts into it SUV's for instance that translates from their sports cars and vice versa! Yes the PDK that you find in a Panamerica,Macan and Cayenne is the same one you get in the 911. Econ 101 does that make it cheaper or more expensive?
While I'm on the topic its clear that you don't grasp what a company like VW gets from the German government vs what US auto makers get. The big three pick up the tab for its workers HC whereas the German government picks up the tab for all its peoples HC.
VW employees included. Its not a one time bailout but is there every year!
So again thanks for coming around!Ôªø
author: Steve Jovan

text:
@Ceasar Clark 
Access to Health care is a major factor in any persons health over a lifetime! Exercise and diet don't stop you from contracting deadly bacteria or viruses. Good choices in terms of diet don't keep you from needing a doctor if you get hit by a car! You don't get to pick your genes thus you either do or do not inherit certain conditions. Access to good health care can mean the difference between living or dying given those realities.Ôªø

author: HenkeEdge

text:
Loved the video,just like I loved last years.

I was rooting for the Shelby,and thought it should've won. I like the McLaren,but I feel like while it's a car that's great to drive,I would NEVER want to drive it here in Chicago on normal streets nor the expressway for fear of pothole/"normal" road conditions and asshole drivers.

I feel like you guys don't take that into account when judging. These cars are tested on the track and on closed long California winding back roads. What about in LA,SF,Chicago,Boston,NYC,or Houston traffic,all of which are considered the worst in the US? Bet a lot of these cars wouldn't be much fun to drive then.

Taking heavy traffic out of the equation,what about just tooling around town at 35~45 mph? Is that McLaren still a great Driver's car?For example, I know that almost every review has said that the GT-R(previous years)is pretty terrible as a daily driver. What about the others?The Viper was the first car eliminated because it's good at only one thing,but you guys completely left out THE most common driving conditions,and that's daily driving.

I hope that next year's list and video will at least try to address this. I would give more thought and insight to how each car drives in more  normal conditions.And I'm not asking for how these cars drive in the rain or snow,but at least just cruising around town.

Thanks again guys. Keep up the good work.Ôªø

text: With Z/28, which had world's widest front tires, US manufacturers realized they could take a big shortcut to higher performance. text: The US market is huge, so huge in fact that US manufactures have not had to expand beyond the USA to make good business, it's as simple as that...  With a single market to play with there has been a lack of innovation in both quality and performance as the consumer base expectations are entirely different to those in Europe. The German manufactures you note have capitalised on the gap in the US and the yanks have been catching up ever since, well until now that is. A major shift in efficient/green direction is leading to the German manufacturers losing the V8's and numbing their performance brands. At the same time the likes of Ford, Chevy are building cars which put outright performance at the forefront beyond anything else. As for the cars being 3 times the price, yes if you want to look at the dollar value, however in relation to competition 1LE, GT350R are all similarly priced in local currency or cheaper than the likes of the BMW M4. As a half Yank/Brit who has lived all over the world I suggest you sit down Fast ER, you have been outgunned.Ôªø
author: StankBeast

text: Outgunned? OK, so where are these wonders of performance? Not anywhere else but in US? Why?? Because most countries (as you mentioned regarding downsizing) tax cars based on engine size. So a 5.0 or 6,2 liter engine in a cheaply made Ford, Camaro or Corvette suddenly gets close to Euro cars in price. And since you have lived all over the world (just like myself) you know that when the price gap is small, people go with what they know and trust, which is the Euro cars. If I lived in US I would go with any of these cheap US cars. It makes sense. But none of them are making any dents globally. Cadillac has tried for over 3 decades and outgunned the Germans in power for 10 years. With no success. Sorry but it's just in a very small demographics (globally) that hp and lap times really numbers. Most yearn for style and class. As do you.Ôªø

text: The new Mustang has done well in most of Europe. It's a V8 we all love and for a low price in most countries. But so far none of these "high end" US cars have come cheap in Europe. All Cadillac models are often even more expensive than their German counterparts. Which results in very few buying them. These performance cars we talk about, they usually have sub standard build quality (that is why they are cheap) and if the price is going to increase too much, they will not find customers in Europe or other parts of the world. As a private person, very few will buy any of these big engine sports cars as gas costs a lot in Europe. Maybe if you buy it as company car or get your gas paid by the company. Even the big engine/power euro cars are bought by rich people here in Europe thanks to gas prices. We all thought the new Stingray would conquer the world. But what happened? It's nowhere to be found and I actually like that car.Ôªø

author: A

text:
+Fast Er -- Firstly, the Camaro SS 1LE is NOT a track car! It is called a track package but other than great brakes, GM magnetic shocks (which Ferrari uses) and VERY small spoilers/nose wings, it is a regular SS. Let's not go overboard there on saying it is a TRACK car. In comparison, the GT350R is more of a track package since it has large spoilers, an illegal street exhaust and the like. You also seem to forget when comparing the GT350R and Camaro 1LE to some of these cars, it is 2 wheel drive (RWD), not all wheel drive (AWD) which DRASTICALLY changes what is needed as far as tyre size. Give these cars credit because it is certainly due! They are true, cross country able cars, unlike the Viper ACR, which has no A/C and is uncomfortable as hell. Having said that, I didn't hear any complaints about lack of comfort in the McLaren 570S. It was the quickest, which is should be around this track for a driver's car which includes all the creature comforts. Why in the hell are we going on about the M4 again? LOL! Check this video if you DO care about Nurburgring times. The 2017 ZL1 Camaro w/10 speed automatic ran a 7:29.60 on a very good, but not perfect lap which is 12 seconds quicker than the last ZL1 and 7 seconds quicker than the 2014/2015 Z/28, which WAS a track model. This ZL1 has dual climate control A/C, backup camera, leather, power seats, power mirrors, etc. Definitely not a track car but it gets it done, QUICKLY and for as little as $62,000 USD! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=R4f4q52J9qY -- Cheers! 
EDIT: -- The MAIN reason the Mustang and Camaro don't make a dent in the European market has SOME to do with the additional expenses of import taxes, etc.along with Germans abundantly preferring German brands (Mercedes Benz is much more reliable than BMW today and was better in the past as well) but what you fail to include is a MUCH larger problem with the UK. They do not produce these models in RHD (right hand drive) nor will they ever because it would never be cost effective for them to do so. The vast majority of the world drives on the right side of the road so LHD (left hand drive) is where the money is. If you were the CEO and wanted to produce lower volume high performance cars for Ford or GM, would YOU have special tooling for these models which are primarily made for the U.S. market? I'm not a BMW hater, I used to own a M3 I6 coupe, a fine car. Later, I owned a M5 V8 w/ a 6-speed manual. It was a fun, mid-sized luxury car. I replaced it with a M-B E55 which was a considerable step up and my cost of ownership was less for the E55 as well. Both cars were purchased new so no, I didn't buy someone else's beater. BMWs are nice cars but they are NOT what they once were. Let's be realistic.
You stated you are 15. I applaud you for being so interested in performance cars. I was much like you when I was that age. Some of us have decades of experience owning and driving them and many other cars. Consider that instead of simply going on about things which you have no personal experience with.
We are all watching these videos for the same reason. We LOVE cars. Let's all get along instead of arguing. It is only counter-productive with negativity instead of concentrating on the positive. Fair enough?Ôªø

author: KenSmitty

text:
+Jonny Lieberman Way to critical of the NSX. 1 second on a short track like laguna seca is fair. 

     It delivers in spirit exactly what the last NSX did while looking even better.... at least in white. The last NSX took the super car formula and gave it a reasonable price tag with good reliability. This time around they took the Hyper car formula and did the same. If you two actually remember the original NSX wasn't all that powerful or fast but it gave people who weren't the one percent the ability to drive a reliable mid-engine screamer. Yes the NSX made the Italians have to deliver a working car but putting the expectation of an industry shake-up or watershed moment on a car just because the last one did it is extremely ridiculous. 
     The original NSX didn't push the bar in terms of technology as much as everyone tries to claim. Its the same thing here, it technically doesn't do anything that hasn't been done before but instead does it at a fraction of the price without monthly maintenance that would bankrupt most people. I'm not saying you made the wrong choice, its probably not the best drivers car and in fact I LOVE the 570GT but you two are just so unbelievably dismissive. And finally I'm tired of cars having to always pay Homage to the previous model, always remembering where they came from like Mufasa fucking spoke to them from the sky. Being forced to stay in the past is why we don't have a decent driving viper and entire generations of boring ass Porsche's that protect the 911. Just make the best car you can I say. 

Also, screw Jason! I'd do things I'm not proud of to own the ACR.Ôªø

author: Alec Clough

text:
So I guess their comments when driving the Mustang prove how little they know about cars in general? Sure, they get paid to drive cars, but they definitely don't know a lot about them. They said the new GT350R is the first true handling and braking muscle car. In 1965 Ford (along with Shelby) took Cobras and GT350R's to the SCCA races. These were road races. BEFORE getting them on a drag strip. You know what happened? The Cobra's never lost a single A-Production championship until SCCA went flop. The GT350R's? They did the EXACT SAME THING IN B-PRODUCTION. Know who had the most factory support in B-Production, who the Mustangs destroyed was? Porsche. Heck, in 1969 the Boss 302's were named Car and Driver's 'Best Handling Production Car" and they retained that distinction - even over all the famous Porsches - until 1981. Sure, brakes are better now than in 1965, but you have to compared car to car at the current time.

Also, did McLaren completely change their car? I thought it was known for having all sorts of computers to do most of the driving for you. But then again, if that's what they consider part of the "Best Driver's Car," then I guess that just goes to show the difference of opinions between an office worker such as these guys and a guy like me who actually races.Ôªø

author: The Channel of Stuff

text:
+Kabob21: It's not quite as simple as you put it, because $2400/ month lease for a McLaren is actually not the real price per month. They will also ask for 10% ($20,000) down with a minimum of a 780 credit rating. This actually is a discussion I have had with my god kids. 

Just because you could make the payment doesn't mean you can afford the car. 

McLaren's are generally only insured by exotic car insurance, most of them limit you to 5-8K miles per year. And they're not cheap either, you'll probably have to spend a minimum of $300-400+ / month and you have to have full coverage (with super high limits) because of the lien on the vehicle. 

Next is maintaining it. I don't know what it costs to maintain one of these, but I know that Rob Ferretti has said he has paid about $9000 for two years of ownership on a late 90s Ferrari 360. Also usually these cars come with tires custom made for their application. Figure $3 to $4k for a set of tires, $2k if you get lucky (Michelin Pilot Sport Cup 2s cost $1600 + shipping + mount and balance) a set on TireRack.com and they're just normal). 

So a two year lease = $2400/month + 20k down payment + 350/month insurance + $2k for just one set of tires + 10k for maintenance + Gas (say 2k for 2/yrs) = $100,000.00 for 2yrs of ownership and after all of that you then have to give the car back to them.Ôªø

author: Khoelle Basnight

text:
A driver's car isn't only a transmission type.  A driver's car is a car that performs extremely well both on road and on track.  It also needs to sound good and make you feel special behind the wheel.  The viper checks for:

Being a car that is amazing on track.
Makes you feel special behind the wheel

It doesn't:
Sound good
Perform well on the road

Since the viper only meets half of the criteria, hence it gets 6th place out of 12.

However, I strongly disagree with choosing the Aston Martin to be last as it meets all of the criteria.

Its fun to drive on the track (randy said it himself) even if it didn't post a good lap time.
Its great on road.
It sounds amazing.
Makes you feel very special behind the wheel.Ôªø

author: John Stephenson

text:
@Nate Eintracht
¬†That is absolutely not true.¬† Where did you get the notion that they stated it was the most fun?¬† Jason aside, who was madly in love with the car even before driving it, none of them were particularly enamored with it at all.
The dog leg is cool, but the transmission doesn't feel well sorted and is difficult to shift.
The engine makes a lot of power, but the car weighs so much it's not fast in a straight line.
It doesn't have good handling dynamics on the limit and doesn't put power down well.

At 7/10ths it might be a great drivers car, but not the best, and it certainly isn't at 10/10ths.Ôªø
author: Dolby109

text:
@Dolby 109 First of all, Jason did drive the Aston before loving it.  Also if you read some of motor trend's articles they do state the Aston Martin V12 Vantage S is tons of fun.  Finally, I think you just watch too much evo or chris harris to the point where you don't know what being good on 7/10s vs being good on 10/10s means.  Being good at 7/10s means that before the limit, the car is great.  Being good at 10/10s means that the car is great on limit.  If a car is good both on 7/10s and 10/10s than it is great driver's car.  If you watched some of the reviews of the Aston Martin v12 Vantage S Manual, everyone says that its on limit behavior is extremely fun and that it has very controllable oversteer.  Its also very good at 7/10s just like you stated.  

Also, i'd just like to point out that the Jaguar F Type SVR was put in 9th place. 9th!!!  Despite Randy loving it the most, despite Jason and Johnny saying it drove beautifully after the suspension got fixed.  They even said that if the suspension didn't show up broken, it would have been the best driver's car.Ôªø

author: Khalil Sulaiman

text:
Let me preface this with the fact that you guys are incredible, you have my dream job, and my respect for how knowledgeable and entertaining the material is. I always look forward to new Motortrend articles, videos, reviews etc... That being said... GT350 R vs McLaren 570S (round of applause for Ford)... I'm sorry, but the foundation of a Driver's Car is three pedals, sensing the feedback from the clutch, feeling the mechanical intimacy as you throw the shifter from gate to gate, satisfying clunks as you gain control the selected gear, heal toe downshifting from 5th to 2nd and knowing exactly how much throttle to blip in order to smoothly put the power down... to all drivers out there: 
GT350 R is the best drivers car.  Automatics, dual clutch or not, shouldn't even be allowed in your next year's choices.Ôªø

author: Davis Dunlap

text:
Did I hear them say the BMW was the best looking car? I guess beauty is in the eye of the beholder, because when I think of attractive autos (form following function) I have never thought BMW. To me they are the utilitarian version of performance luxury, sort of like the camry of the performance/luxury market. I guess in a word, basic. 
I think people find it attractive not for it's shape, proportions, or details, but because it is a BMW and they project what that entails.
Kind of like an experiment I saw where they showed a picture of an average looking guy to groups of women to gauge his attractiveness. When the ladies were led to believe he had special talents and was successful in some way most women found him very attractive, even those who previously thought otherwise. By the same token if women were led to believe he was unsuccessful and had no known special talents, he was found to be unattractive or average at best. And before you say gold diggers, they had similar examples for men gauging women with similar results.
However there are some extremes that despite the backstory are found attractive or not regardless. I think at best BMW is an extremely average looking car overall, however there are some exceptions like the old M1 or Z8.Ôªø

author: 1001speedster

text: @kabob21 Then why the out of date Aston, it clearly isn't new. A 10 year old Aston design but not a 2 yr old P1. And why test the Camaro and Mustang at all? I know the Mustang came in second, but a mass produced assembly line car will never win against a hand made carbon fiber tub supercar. Its a great show though.Ôªø
author: Mike Howard

text:
Because that particular Vantage S V12 is a special edition that's only out this year before the DB11 rolls out and its successor comes. It's also unique in that it's the only new car in America with a V12 and a manual transmission. And it's a dogleg transmission, to boot. Why wouldn't you include it?

I don't follow your logic with that second comment. Almost all cars here are "mass-produced assembly line" cars. Some are more handmade than others. The GT-R, AMG, GT350R, Viper, AM Vanquish all have hand-built engines. The GT350R isn't just some regular ol' Mustang, either. It was designed and engineering by Ford Performance Engineering and share little with the rest of the Mustang lineup other than the chassis, a few body panels, the interior and headlights.Ôªø
author: kabob21

text: @kabob21  The GT350R's FPC voodoo is handbuilt but was not designed like the McLaren's. The voodoo had to go with a heavier crank because there was no room for  individual intake plenums for each side, why, because its a production car first and changes like that wouldn't fit the assembly line. McLaren and Ferrari build cars without limits from ordinary production designs. If you had a 918,a 675LT, and a 488, I don't think the Mustang would make the top three. I think if value was a weightier consideration the GT350R would win hands down as the best drivers car though.Ôªø

text: As they've said repeatedly, this is a Best Drivers Car competition, not a Best Value competition.Ôªø

text:
You could get one 570S, or one fleet containing the 1) 911 2) Camaro SS 1LE and 3) Shelby GT350R.

author: Rishabh Rander

text:
This was great: kind of! Props to camera and editor peoples for the quality of the video.

What was missing though was the rest of the MT staff. What happened to all of them? I'm sure the mag/print article will have exerts from them but I miss Angus and Ed and even Kim: we see Kin in the video but what did he have to say or anyone else?

I hope MT does a special return episode of WOT. For those of you who don't know or remember what that is, Wide Open Throttle used to be the round table discussion videos with a group of editors and regular MT staffers that was interesting to watch and listen too. 

It may have been 'inside baseball' type of talk but it was where ideas and different thoughts were thrown and hashed out. The 2016 MT-BDCOTY really needs a WOT episode. I;m left kind of empty by the whole thing, even after 39 minuets!

Jonny we talked about this last year in Detroit and I was hoping all spring. summer and now fall for the return of WOT but well, I guess not. Maybe I'll see you in Detroit again this coming January and I'll make sure to speak to you once again.Ôªø

text: The Mclaren makes sense. Also a car I could Never Ever own. So relevance to me as the ultimate driver's car no. The Ultimate Drivers car to me says I am approachable, and not only 3 people can own it. I get the Exclusivity part of it. I really do. I think the Camaro to me knocks it out of the park. Yes, the GT350 is great no doubt. But even that is allot of money. I love cars that exceed way beyond their playing field, and the Camaro got it right. I cannot wait for the Z28, and the ZL-1 to wipe up the floor with the GT350, or at least keep the game interesting between Mustang, and Camaro. I am amazed Corvette wasn't here too. The C7 is amazing, but the Camaro again has so much, for so relatively reasonable means. But to come back, yeah, the Mclaren is the winner. As always, I love the BDC and all the Motor Trend vids. author: Daniel G

text:
Great production overall. This was extremely well done. 

That said, sorry guys, I refuse to believe that the McLaren is as good as the GT350R on a back road or the track OVERALL. Sure, it's probably faster, but there is no way that it has the character of the Shelby. That engine makes you smile even when you're only driving it easy. I'm glad to see it at least got runner up, though. I am certainly biased, but having also taken part in the experience of that car, it's otherwordly.Ôªø

author: Bal√°zs Risk√≥

text:
Last year the Merc deserved it....

This year the Mustang deserved it, but I can't help but feel like McLaren bought it.......

Personally, I just don't like the ass on that McLaren and it's just too damn much money. I have to give it to Mustang for performance, looks and price/value. I think it's the clear winner because it almost did it all at a fraction of the cost. 

But if I wanted to wipe down my car with a diaper and just stare at it for hours and fall asleep in it at night because I love it so much......... The Porsche! Ohhhhhh soooooo beautiful in that blue!Ôªø
author: Tickle Fingers

text: Bought it? Like McLaren paid us?Ôªø
author: Jonny Lieberman

text:
Not quite literally...... In a way I'm saying that it seems like something greased the wheels to slide it over to McLarens favor. Its just feels like the Ford (to me) was the clear winner. And I don't really like Fords.... They did much more for less, packed in fun, gave the car bells and whistles normally at a higher price point, had the balance between grocery getter and track star and is something an aspiring individual will more likely be able to obtain. 

The McLaren is something most will never see in their lives. It may be a "drivers car" but it's only a car for a select few. Where as the GT350R could probably be more easily purchased or recreated. 

And I just can't get onboard with the styling...... 
Ôªø

author: Marc Showman

text:
The annual BDC is one of my favorite shows on Youtube. I loved the lead up -- the presentation of the hot laps was the best yet. The production values in this one were also the highest yet. But it wasn't until you started eliminating cars that the video became any damn good. I usually enjoy the humor you've brought into your videos since Jason joined the team, but it got very annoying here. Whenever you have a competition of any kind there's a story being told and as reviewers it is your job to tell us that story. It got real muddled. I understand why you liked the Shelby and why you didn't like the Viper. I never got any sense for why the Audi and the AMG weren't top 3 material (not that I like them more than the others, but what was the point of even including them in this video if you weren't going to say anything more than "Meh"?). I didn't even realize you liked the McLaren until the end and I'd suggest that twist endings aren't the best way to perform a car review.

Again, I want to make clear that I like a lot of what you guys do and that the lead up to this was fantastic. I'm just shocked that in a stacked BDC competition like this, you had to pad the running time.Ôªø

author: Sihyung Park

text:
Hey guys, firstly thanks for a week of nice entertainment. I always like Best Driver's Car because it is about taking great cars and nitpicking at their differences to find the greatest for that year. It is also about what you can't just see in numbers, the feel, what the driver actually experiences. So why do I feel like there was so little of that in this video? For example, what we got in this video about the 911 Carrera S:

No on road driving footage or info
Back seat bs with lots of acronyms
‚ÄúWhat a time for a car with not a lot of horsepower! But a trustworthy car even in the backseat.‚Äù
‚ÄúOn street tires.‚Äù
‚ÄúPorsche added power and made their car even better. I never loved the 991 chassis 911s when they came out. They keep making all these improvements and man are they getting close to making the perfect 911 now!‚Äù
‚ÄúI‚Äôve always loved this generation of 911, and this is the best one yet. In fact that thing could be our best driver‚Äôs car.‚Äù
‚Ä¶3rd place trophy.

Seriously?! There is no information whatsoever about how it DRIVES. It could maybe be forgiven if you glanced over a middle of the pack contender (not great or bad - even though each car in such an elite group deserves to be talked about), but a 3rd place finisher? And the 911 wasn't the only one.

Now don't get me wrong, I would have enjoyed this video even if you guys didn't give one word of info...the sound and cinematography is just brilliant! I even enjoy the humor. I just feel it could have been more - it could have been best DRIVER'S car.Ôªø

text: Well, chaps, Jace and Jonny....we commend you from across The Pond.  Excellent show, more wit than Chris Evans (am I damning with faint praise....?)...plus,  an objective (570s) AND subjective (AM Vantage V12 S) decision which, being a Brit, I wholly support.     That V12 acoustic range is utterly superb but having driven the 570s at Millbrook, UK,  I can honestly inform my US cousins that you will never (ever ?) drive anything with so much natural, intuitive, fun and 'James-May-fizzy-bits-inducing' mechanical grip. author: Biscuit

text:
I'm a Porsche guy, and that 911 is absolutely terrific, but the new 570S is genuinely brilliant. Well-deserved. GT350R also definitely deserved second spot. I'm not a muscle-car guy, but that engine is spectacular, and the sounds it makes are orgasmic. First muscle car I'd consider getting actually (old Z28 was great but nah). 

Best daily driver that's super fun though? Still the 911. Glad it's in top three. 

NSX is a disappointment. 

GTR doesn't add anything to the table. 

AMG GT S is still a great car, nothing's changed. 

M4 GTS is a bit too much hype. 

R8 V10 Plus is a good car, but not 570S good. 

F-Type SVR is another heavy Jag with more power than handling. Not my type of vehicle. It's basically what a Range Rover would be if they dropped it 10 inches lower to the ground. 

Aston Martin wanted to make a giveaway for an end of an era, and gave us the V12 S. I reckon they should've tested a GT8 (6-speed manual) or a GT12. 

Camaro SS 1LE really isn't that special. It's fast but it doesn't actually drive well. User-inputs aren't refined at all, and that engine isn't really special. Oh and did I mention how god-awful bad it looks?

Great BDC Ending, looking forward to the drag race...Ôªø

text: I personally find that choosing the McLaren over the gt350r for best drivers car isn't the best choice.  They said that the car is an extension of the driver and that's why it won for best driver isn't really true.  For starters not all of us can afford a $200,000 super car with only like 50 more Horsepower than the Shelby.  But unlike the McLaren the Shelby has a true 6 speed manual which makes that car a better extension of the driver because they have to know how to drive the car right instead of letting a computer shift the gears for them. So in my opinion the Shelby is the better drivers car given that more people can afford it and have to be more involved with the driving experience. But just my opinion,  everyone has their own.Ôªø

text:
I can't argue the fact that the McLaren is an awesome car but it should be crown the 2016 Best Drivers Car (if money is no issue). I know the same argument can be made for past winners like the AMG and the 911, but the fact that the Shelby GT350R is $62k (before $25k mark up) it is the true winner! Lets call it the 2016 Best Drivers Car (without praying to win the lottery). Lets not even talking about... Wait! Lets, the fact that there is a Non R Model that will blow your ears and mind for $8k less than the the R. Same engine, same power and same smile on your face that will get permanently stuck. Congrats to Ford. 
 On a side note it was a great video. I literally laughed out loud a few times. Keep them coming, can"t wait for more.Ôªø

author: Kenneth Dike

text:
For what the 570S costs, it damn well better have won.  If I'm going to pay $200,000 for a car, it better be the absolute best at what it's made to do.

That said, 99% of us don't have that kind of scratch. Maybe I'm a cheapskate, but I'm looking at this in a different light--not the absolute best driver's car, but the best driver's car for the price. Looking at this field, it's pretty obvious that when you look at the value-for-money angle, the Mustang and Camaro are probably your best bets. Both of these cars are competing (and in some cases beating) cars that cost twice or more what they do. Sure the McLaren is a better driver's car than the Shelby, but is it $140,000 better? I strongly doubt that.Ôªø

author: Dale Walker

text:
Exactly right. The 1LE is absolutely the best driver's car for the money, and coming within 1 second of the GT350R's time means it's better value for money than every other car in this video. Especially because they said it was one of the cars that was both fast AND fun.

nothing against the 350R per se, but the 1LE costs a LOT less money and is  90%+ as fast on a track.Ôªø

author: Reginald Pierre

text: as americans, and as an american. Im positive any chance MT has a chance to stick it to the rest of the world they do it.........between the shelby 350r, 1le, and acr they proved how they can compete though i knew the viper was as track focused as the list got....and knew it was hell anywhere else to drive... They are always still a very practical choice. Especially in regards to maintenance and longevity. No "bells and whistles tech of the era" dampening systems or ridiculous gimmicks that will be obsolete in a next generation of cars time....which will be over priced to tune/repair. My definition of practical might not be the same as others but if in 20 years you can still get parts at a reasonable price thats nice to know...then again a porsche probably is #1 in that boat of longevity i just never trust these "new from the ground up v8 or v6 twin turbo" nonsense the engine hasnt been put through the rigors of 10-20 years of abuse...also why i will trust a nissan engine/product. Only time will tell with the voodoo i guess or the direct injection LT4....Still funny to think that GM/Cadillac produces magnetic rear suspension system and you apply it to the mustang and guess what it is that much more of a performer, some people dont know or understand this lmao....that gm is in part to thank to why the 350r is "so much better than the camaro" which the 1le/SS which they pit them against also has magneride lmao. Its a must for any track car thats supposed to feel firm but not stiff brilliant all mustangs should have it and same to camaros lmao both should have 15" rotors and 4 disk brembos lmao. What a time for Cars especially my favorite pony cars i cant wait to see what nissan has in store for the next z and gt-r. Still as bad as it sounds(since zs are supposed 6s) but to enter into gt racing i wish they made a quad cam v8 for the z like a 4 litre or so.....since bmw audi and benz has been in the v8 quad cam gt racing game for years now i guess dtm+gt3 fit their bill...i just would like to see nissan back at it....i know they have a 5.0 and i think a 4.6 quad cam but like a 4.0 for gt3 would be sick then again its what the gt-r is for....still to win class gt3 and gt1 would be bad ass...Ôªø

author: Michael Greco

text:
The best part is, you can watch both.

I like both - Evos delivery is typically a bit more sober and arguably more oriented towards the technical, historical and perhaps the artistry of the cars; Motor Trend is arguably more fun.

It's definitely interesting to see where opinions divide between the two though.

FWIW I've been active daily on the Evo Mag car forum for over a decade (terrifying thought...), and only really started following MotorTrend because of Roadkill  and checked out some of the other content (ignition, dirt every day, head to head, etc) and enjoyed it.

The content from Evo and Motor Trend are both really, really good though.

If you like Evo, do check out Harrys Garage, though - the ex MD/owner of Evo, going through his personal collection of cars, which are as esoteric and special as you would expect.Ôªø

author: wouterdonna

text:
Hmm... 
I'm not sure I agree with the order of the top 3. First they didn't properly explain why they placed the Porsche 3rd. 2nd I don't think they factored in the driving involment of the manual on the GT 350R. 3rd I don't think they justified the price premium in the 570S. 

Most people who buy a car like that don't drive it on track or even close to that quick on the street. As they stated at the beginning of the video all these mid engine super/hypercars are way too fast for the street. They also said that the car must be usable on track and street. I don't think there are many roads that are smooth enough that you could really drive the 570S without being afraid of destroying the bumper

A drivers car should be involving, exciting, great handling and also something you could really throw around everywhere... I think that's the GT 350R... It ticks all the boxes and is not so fast that you can't let it loose whenever you want. They even say that it is special no matter how fast your going.

Motortrend needs to clean themselves up a bit. I find they focus so much more on entertainment (which is may more shouty then I would like) There needs to be more substance and less contradictions in there statements.Ôªø

text:
So glad that the Mclaren took the title... Let's be honest, Mclaren were doing their best and improving their cars since the new era, the 12C wasn't that perfect but things got corrected with the 650S , then the crazy idea of building the 675LT was another successful improvement...  Jumping to the 570S, oh god, a sportscar feeling with supercars performance aaaaand it's so comfy in high speeds and crazy driving... it's handles so great and the car looks gorgeous (that's my opinion), the interior also is a big improvement and i got to say that is the interior Mclaren have ever made (not talking about the 3 seater F1 ;) )

author: Ruri Gokou

text:
Only once. Most sale prices depend on the area of sale. In Texas and California, they are still going for ~$5k over, but since they released, in the Mid-West they have been selling for ~$0-2k over from the beginning. It's all about supply and demand. 
Even with a $20k markup (which is the highest single markup recorded for the gt350, not the average) you could have 2 gt350s and an extra $35k for the price of that McLaren. 
I love both cars, but man is that Mustang a deal. Also, I'm a little bias, I've only ever owned Fords. Plus, I just bought a '16 Fiesta ST (which is freakin great btw).

Food for thought :)Ôªø
